name: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
synopsis: After being bitten by a radioactive spider, Brooklyn teen Miles Morales gets a crash course in web-slinging from his alternate-dimension counterparts.
spoilers:
Rating 7: New York City teenager Miles Morales struggles to live up to the expectations of his father, police officer Jefferson Davis, who sees Spider-Man as a menace.
Rating 8: Miles adjusts to prep school, and visits his uncle Aaron Davis, who takes him to an abandoned subway station to paint graffiti.
Rating 10: Miles is bitten by a radioactive spider and gains spider-like abilities similar to Spider-Man.
Rating 3: Returning to the station, Miles discovers a collider built by Wilson Fisk, who hopes to access parallel universes to bring back his late wife and son, whose deaths he blames on Spider-Man.
Rating 8: Miles watches as Spider-Man attempts to disable the collider while fighting Fisk's henchmen, Green Goblin and the Prowler.
Rating 4: Spider-Man saves Miles, but Green Goblin shoves Spider-Man into the collider, causing an explosion that kills Goblin and wounds Spider-Man.
Rating 8: Spider-Man gives Miles a USB flash drive designed to disable the collider, warning that the machine could destroy the city if reactivated.
Rating 3: After watching in horror as Fisk kills Spider-Man, Miles flees with Prowler in pursuit, eventually getting away from him.
Rating 3: As the city mourns Spider-Man's death, Miles tries to honor his legacy and become the new Spider-Man.
Rating 10: While trying out his newfound abilities, he inadvertently damages the drive.
Rating 3: At Spider-Man's grave, Miles meets Peter B. Parker, an older and worn-down version of Spider-Man from another dimension.
Rating 8: Upon meeting him, Miles discovers his ability to emit bio-electric bursts called "venom-blasts".
Rating 7: Peter reluctantly agrees to train Miles in exchange for help stealing data to create a new drive.
Rating 8: They infiltrate Fisk's research facility, and Miles discovers he has the power to turn invisible.
Rating 3: They are confronted by mad scientist Olivia Octavius, who discovers that Peter will die from cellular decay if he remains in their dimension.
Rating 10: Chased through the laboratory and surrounding forest by Octavius, Miles and Peter are saved by Gwen Stacy, a Spider-Woman from another dimension.
Rating 3: They then visit the deceased Spider-Man's aunt, May Parker, who is sheltering more Spider-people from other dimensions—Spider-Man Noir, Peni Parker, and Spider-Ham—who are also deteriorating.
Rating 10: Miles offers to disable the collider so the others can return home, but after questioning and testing him, they tell him that he lacks experience.
Rating 8: Distraught, Miles retreats to Aaron's home, where he discovers Aaron is the Prowler.
Rating 8: Miles returns to May's house, where Peni has completed the new drive; he is followed by Fisk, Prowler, Octavius, Scorpion, and Tombstone.
Rating 3: In the ensuing brawl, Miles reveals his identity to Aaron just as Aaron corners him.
Rating 8: Unwilling to kill his own nephew, Aaron spares Miles, but is fatally shot by Fisk.
Rating 3: Miles flees with Aaron, who tells him to keep going before dying.
Rating 3: Jefferson arrives on the scene and Miles escapes, leading Jefferson to mistake Spider-Man as Aaron's murderer.
Rating 6: The heroes regroup with a devastated Miles at his dorm room.
Rating 8: Peter restrains Miles to ensure his safety and leaves with the others, choosing to sacrifice himself by staying behind and deactivating the collider.
Rating 10: Jefferson arrives outside Miles' door and, assuming Miles does not want to speak to him, apologizes for his mistakes and inspires Miles.
Rating 10: Miles then manages to control his powers, escapes his restraints, and creates his own Spider-Man suit with May's help.
Rating 10: He joins the heroes, defeating Fisk's enforcers and using the new drive to send them home.
Rating 10: Fisk fights Miles, attracting the attention of Jefferson, who realizes that Spider-Man isn't the menace he saw him as.
Rating 10: Jefferson encourages Miles, who subdues Fisk with his venom-blast and throws him at the kill switch, causing the collider to explode and saving the city.
Rating 10: Fisk and his henchmen are arrested for their crimes and Jefferson recognizes the new Spider-Man as a hero while receiving evidence of Fisk's murders of Peter and Aaron.
Rating 10: Miles embraces the responsibilities of his new life, while the heroes return to their lives in their own dimensions.
Rating 6: Later, Gwen finds a way to contact Miles from her own dimension.
Rating 3: In another dimension, Miguel O'Hara, also known as Spider-Man 2099, travels to Earth-67 and argues with its Spider-Man.

name: Extraction
synopsis: A hardened gun-for-hire's latest mission becomes a soul-searching race to survive when he's sent into Bangladesh to rescue a drug lord's kidnapped son.
spoilers:
Rating 3: Ovi Mahajan Jr. – son of incarcerated Indian drug lord Ovi Mahajan Sr. – sneaks out of his house to visit a club with his friend.
Rating 8: At the party, they go to the garage to have a smoke, where they encounter corrupt police officers working for rival Bangladeshi drug lord Amir Asif, who shoot Ovi Jr.'s friend and kidnap him.
Rating 3: After discovering this, Saju Rav — a former Lieutenant Colonel in the Indian Army Para Special Forces and Ovi' Jr.'s protector — visits Ovi' Sr. in prison.
Rating 10: Unwilling to pay the ransom or surrender his territories to Amir as it will hurt his prestige, Ovi Sr. orders Saju to retrieve his son, threatening to kill Saju's own son if he is unwilling to do so.
Rating 3: Tyler Rake, a former Australian Army SASR operator turned black-market operations mercenary, is recruited by his partner and fellow mercenary, Nik Khan to save Ovi Jr. from Dhaka, Bangladesh.
Rating 3: Tyler and Khan's team prepare to extract Ovi Jr., with Ovi Sr. men set to pay them once Ovi Jr. is recovered.
Rating 10: Tyler saves Ovi Jr., kills his captors and takes him to the extraction point.
Rating 7: Learning of Ovi Jr.'s escape, Asif orders the head of the local police, Colonel Rashid, to initiate an immediate lockdown of Dhaka, securing all bridges and travel points out of the city.
Rating 10: Ovi Sr.'s men intentionally fail to transfer the funds as it is revealed that Ovi Sr.'s bank account has been frozen by the authorities, so he had no means to pay the mercenaries in the first place.
Rating 10: Saju kills Tyler's teammates and tries to kill Tyler, so he can save Ovi Jr. himself and cheat the mercenaries out of their payment.
Rating 10: Khan arranges for a helicopter to extract Tyler outside the city and tells him to abandon Ovi Jr. since the contract has been nullified.
Rating 5: Tyler refuses to leave Ovi Jr. behind, haunted by memories of his own son, whom he abandoned after he couldn't stand seeing him suffer from lymphoma any longer.
Rating 3: After escaping Saju and the corrupt Dhaka Metropolitan Police tactical units on Asif's payroll, Tyler fights off a gang of boys led by Farhad, a young criminal eager to impress Asif.
Rating 10: Tyler calls his friend Gaspar, a retired American squad-mate living in Dhaka, and he and Ovi Jr. lay low at Gaspar's home for the evening.
Rating 3: Gaspar reveals Asif has placed a $10,000,000 bounty on Ovi Jr., which he offers to share if Tyler allows him to kill the boy.
Rating 6: He refuses and fights Gaspar, who gains the upper hand, but is shot and killed by Ovi with Gaspar's own gun.
Rating 3: Tyler calls Saju and asks for his help, forcing them to team up to escape Dhaka.
Rating 10: Tyler draws attention away from a disguised Saju and Ovi Jr. as the two make their way through a bridge checkpoint before following to cover their escape.
Rating 7: Khan and her remaining mercenaries approach from the opposite side of the bridge, as Asif watches from afar with binoculars.
Rating 4: In the ensuing firefight, Saju is shot and killed by Rashid, who is in turn shot and killed by Khan.
Rating 3: Wounded, Tyler instructs Ovi Jr. to run to Khan's waiting helicopter.
Rating 3: As a badly wounded Tyler follows, he is shot in the neck by Farhad and seeing Ovi Jr. is safe, falls into the river.
Rating 3: Ovi Jr., Khan and the extraction team escape to Mumbai for safety.
Rating 10: Eight months later, Khan encounters Asif in a restroom and promptly shoots him to death.
Rating 8: Ovi Jr. jumps into his school's swimming pool to practice holding his breath, mirroring the scene where Tyler is introduced chronologically in the film.
Rating 5: He surfaces to see a blurred vision of a man resembling Tyler watching him.

name: Kantara
synopsis: A fiery young man clashes with an unflinching forest officer in a south Indian village where spirituality, fate and folklore rule the lands.
spoilers:
Rating 8: In 1847, there lived a king that had a great kingdom as well as a loving wife and child, but could not find peace.
Rating 10: He sets out on a journey to discover true happiness and comes upon a holy stone in a forest occupied by Panjurli Daiva , a deity that protects the villagers that reside in the forest.
Rating 6: He donates vast portion of his land to the villagers in exchange for taking the stone with him.
Rating 8: Panjurli warns the king that his family and successors should keep their word and not reclaim the land, which will incur the wrath of Panjurli's companion, the ferocious Goblin named Guliga Daiva.
Rating 10: In 1970, the King's successor asks a Bhoota Kola performer, who is possessed by Panjurli to make the locals hand over the land to him, which the performer refuses and states he will die vomiting blood if he tries to reclaim it.
Rating 10: The successor raises doubt on performer's possession by Panjurli, to which the performer replies he would vanish if he is possessed, after which he runs into the forest and is indeed never seen again.
Rating 10: As warned, the king's successor dies mysteriously, vomiting blood a few months later on the steps of the court, where he was going to argue the land case.
Rating 10: In 1990, Murali, a forest officer, is tasked with converting the villagers' land into a forest reserve.
Rating 3: However, he is challenged by Shiva, a Kambala athlete from the Kaadubettu village and the missing performer's son.
Rating 10: Shiva is backed by his patron and the village's landlord, Devendra Suttooru, who is the king's successor in the present.
Rating 8: Although Shiva is continually asked to perform the Bhoota Kola, he refuses due to the trauma of his father's disappearance.
Rating 6: Instead, his cousin Guruva takes his place.
Rating 3: Murali and his staff start erecting a fence along the earmarked forest reserve.
Rating 10: Shiva falls in love with his friend Leela and uses his connections with Devendra to appoint her as a forest guard.
Rating 10: The villagers try to stop the fencing, but the police and forest guards  brutally suppress them, creating a rift between Leela and Shiva even though she was following orders and could do nothing about the situation.
Rating 8: As the feud between Murali and Shiva intensifies, Murali decides to arrest Shiva and his friends and heads to their hideout along with Devendra's henchman Sudhakara.
Rating 10: During the search, Murali's jeep accidentally gets crushed by the trunk of a tree, which was cut by Shiva as the latter didn't expect Jeep on the way.
Rating 3: While Murali survives with severe injury, Shiva and his companions go undercover to avoid arrest.
Rating 8: A few days later, they return to the village to meet their families; Shiva makes up with Leela and tells her that he will surrender.
Rating 7: However, they are caught by the police and forest guards the morning after.
Rating 8: Guruva asks Devendra to bail Shiva, but during conversation Devendra instead tries to bribe him to act as if Panjurli orders the villagers to give him their land in the next Bhoota Kola, revealing his true intention of acquiring his ancestral land given by his predecessor to villagers.
Rating 10: Guruva refuses and Devendra kills him; learning that Murali has figured out his ulterior motive, Devendra decides to set Shiva against him.
Rating 8: Having learnt about Guruva's death, Shiva meets Devendra, who lies that Murali is the Guruva's killer.
Rating 3: Enraged, Shiva goes to kill Murali, but learns from his blacksmith friend Mahadeva that Devendra himself killed Guruva.
Rating 9: Shiva is attacked by Devendra's henchmen, but manages to escape and meet the villagers, whom Murali has told about Devendra's land seizure.
Rating 10: After Shiva reveals that Devendra killed Guruva, he and Murali set aside their grudge and unite the village.
Rating 8: Devendra and his henchmen attack, leading to an intense battle where several of the villagers are killed.
Rating 8: After nearly dying in the fight, Shiva hits his head against Panjurli's stone.
Rating 4: Suddenly, he becomes possessed by the Guliga Daiva.
Rating 6: Due to that possession, Shiva brutally kills Devendra and his henchmen.
Rating 10: A few months after the battle, Shiva performs the Bhoota Kola, and is possessed by Panjurli, where he, Murali and the villagers join hands in a symbolic gesture.
Rating 7: Later, Shiva disappears into the forest after meeting what seems to be his father's spirit.
Rating 3: In the mid-credits scene, Shiva and Leela's son asks Sundara about his father's disappearance.

name: Mission Majnu
synopsis: In the 1970s, an undercover Indian spy takes on a deadly mission to expose a covert nuclear weapons program in the heart of Pakistan.
spoilers:
Rating 8: In 1971, Amandeep "Aman" Singh IPS is a deep cover RAW field operative, who is in Pakistan on an undercover assignment under the pseudonym Tariq Hussain.
Rating 10: Along the way, Aman falls in love with Nasreen Hussain, a blind girl and the two get married.
Rating 10: In May 1974, India conducted its first nuclear test, due to which Pakistan secretly rushed to build its own nuclear weapon with the help of nuclear engineer Abdul Qadeer Khan.
Rating 10: During the 1977 Indian general election campaign, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is appraised of the situation by RAW Chief R. N. Kao, and she directs him to find the location of the nuclear facility.
Rating 3: Kao assigns the mission to Aman.
Rating 8: Aman's handler, Sharma, informs him of his new mission named "Mission Majnu".
Rating 10: Along the way, Aman meets two other RAW agents - Aslam Usmaniya and Raman Singh , who are stationed in Pakistan.
Rating 8: Aman manages to gather information that Pakistan is indeed making a nuclear weapon.
Rating 10: Following a general election in India, a new government is formed and its new leader and new Prime Minister Morarji Desai believes in building relationships through diplomacy and peaceful means, and is against any form of warfare including spying and intelligence gathering.
Rating 10: Kao resigns to keep the operation in Pakistan going, and hidden from the Prime Minister.
Rating 10: In the meantime, Israel is readying an attack on the Quetta military facility, wrongly believing it to be a nuclear weapon facility.
Rating 10: Aman manages to locate the nuclear facility in Kahuta, but is unable to collect physical evidence.
Rating 3: Sharma discovers that Israel is going to attack Quetta in 48 hours.
Rating 3: Aman goes back to Kahuta and collects hair of Army personnel working in the nuclear facility, which he surreptitiously sends to India, where it is tested and found to contain trace amounts of radiation, pointing to the presence of plutonium in Kahuta.
Rating 3: Israel's attack on Quetta is averted.
Rating 3: The matter is disclosed to Desai In light of new evidence, where he weighs in on Pakistan counterparts and Pakistan's inability to be trusted.
Rating 4: ISI hunts down and kills covert RAW agents operating in Pakistan including Aman's colleagues Aslam and Raman.
Rating 8: Aman tries to escape to Dubai with a pregnant Nasreen, who is unaware that ISI agents are chasing them.
Rating 10: Aman distracts ISI agents long enough to let Nasreen board an aeroplane and leave unhindered but is killed in the process.
Rating 8: Nasreen lands in Dubai, where she meets Kao at the airport and reads a letter from Aman revealing his true identity.

name: RRR
synopsis: A fearless warrior on a perilous mission comes face to face with a steely cop serving British forces in this epic saga set in pre-independent India.
spoilers:
Rating 8: In 1920, during the British Raj, Governor Scott Buxton and his wife Catherine visit a forest in Adilabad.
Rating 3: There they abduct Malli, an artistically-talented young girl from the Gond tribe.
Rating 3: Enraged, the tribe's guardian Komaram Bheem embarks for Delhi to rescue her, disguising himself as a Muslim named Akhtar.
Rating 6: Elsewhere, the Nizamate of Hyderabad, sympathetic to the Raj, warns Scott's office of the impending danger.
Rating 3: Undeterred, Catherine enlists A. Rama Raju, an ambitious officer in the Indian Imperial Police, to quell the threat.
Rating 3: Seeking clues to Malli's whereabouts, Raju and his uncle, Venkateswarulu, attend several pro-independence gatherings where he feigns to support independence.
Rating 8: Months later, Lachhu, Bheem's gullible aide, believing Raju's ruse, attempts to recruit him into Bheem's plot.
Rating 9: Before introducing Raju to Bheem, Lachhu discovers Bheem's identity as a police officer and flees.
Rating 3: Shortly after, Bheem and Raju encounter each other, unaware of their opposing allegiances.
Rating 10: While working in concert to save a boy from a train wreck, they form a friendship, gradually growing close.
Rating 3: Raju assists Bheem in courting Jenny, Scott's niece, unaware that Bheem plans to infiltrate Scott's residence.
Rating 10: When Jenny takes Bheem to her residence, Bheem locates the room where Malli is held captive; he promises Malli to free her.
Rating 8: Meanwhile, Raju deduces Lachhu's true identity and apprehends him.
Rating 7: While being interrogated, Lachhu goads a banded krait into attacking Raju, then warns him of his imminent fate and that the antidote is only known to the Gonds.
Rating 3: Dazed, Raju approaches Bheem, who immediately tends to him.
Rating 3: Noticing similar religious features between Lachhu and Bheem, Raju deduces his true intentions.
Rating 8: Nevertheless, Bheem divulges his tribal identity and his mission, still unaware of Raju's true identity.
Rating 3: At an event to honor Scott, Bheem's men barge into his residence with a lorry filled with wild animals, creating havoc among the guests.
Rating 5: The animals maul Scott's guards, allowing Bheem to briefly fight; however, Raju arrives and tells him Scott intends to kill Malli; he surrenders out of obligation.
Rating 8: In the aftermath, Raju is promoted for thwarting Bheem, yet he is guilt-stricken over his actions, recalling his own pro-nationalistic background and his alter-ego as a mole within the police; he sought a promotion to gain access to gun shipments to smuggle to his village.
Rating 10: At Bheem's public flogging, Raju attempts to persuade him to recant his actions; Bheem chooses flogging instead.
Rating 8: Bheem sings in defiance of his injuries, which incites the assembled crowd into rebellion.
Rating 10: The riot further enlightens Raju, who finally recognizes his reckless actions.
Rating 8: Determined to save his friend, he persuades Scott to execute Bheem in secrecy, while Raju prepares an ambush to rescue Bheem.
Rating 10: Scott figures out the scheme.
Rating 10: While rescuing Malli from Scott's men, Raju is grievously injured.
Rating 8: Bheem, who freed himself, mistakenly interprets Raju's actions as an attempt to kill Malli; he bludgeons him and escapes with her.
Rating 8: Months later, Bheem, who is hiding with his group and Malli in Hathras, is cornered by the colonial authorities.
Rating 8: He narrowly avoids being exposed when Sita, Raju's fiancée, repels them by claiming there is a smallpox epidemic.
Rating 3: Unaware of Bheem's identity, she reveals Raju's anti-colonial objectives and his impending execution.
Rating 8: Crestfallen upon realizing his own folly, Bheem vows to save him.
Rating 10: With Jenny's sympathetic assistance, Bheem infiltrates the barracks where Raju is detained and frees him.
Rating 8: The pair retreat to a nearby forest, where they decimate soldiers with a longbow taken from a Rama shrine.
Rating 8: Taking the fight to Scott, they hurl a flaming motorcycle into the barracks' magazines, setting it afire.
Rating 10: Bheem steals a cache of guns for Raju before the barracks is destroyed.
Rating 8: The subsequent explosion kills many within Scott's company, including Catherine.
Rating 5: Having cornered a wounded Scott, Raju has Bheem execute him with a British rifle, fulfilling their respective objectives.
Rating 10: Ram is reunited with Sita, and Bheem is reunited with Jenny and his family.
Rating 10: To mark the mission's successful completion, Raju asks Bheem to make a wish he can grant; Bheem asks Raju to provide education for him and his community.

name: Shehzada
synopsis: After realizing he was switched at birth by a conniving father, a rakish Bantu’s life is upended when he becomes the heir to a billionaire.
spoilers:
Rating 8: Valmiki and Randeep start their career as clerks in the company of Aditya Jindal.
Rating 8: Randeep, who marries Jindal's daughter Yashoda "Yashu", becomes wealthy while Valmiki remains poor.
Rating 10: On the day of the birth of both their children, Randeep's son appears to be dead.

Rating 8: After switching them, however, Randeep's child begins to cry, having not died after all.

Rating 10: 25 years later, Raj, raised at Jindal's house, is timid and innocent while Bantu, raised by Valmiki, is street-smart and outspoken.
Rating 10: Valmiki, who favours  his own son Raj, treats Bantu badly.

Rating 8: Meanwhile, Raj returns from his studies abroad.

Rating 8: but she and Bantu have fallen in love.

Rating 5: Bantu denounces Valmiki as his father.

Rating 3: Bantu begins to address the issues plaguing the house by patching up Randeep relationship with Yashu, which had been strained since Randeep's affair seven years ago.

Rating 10: Bantu unites with Randeep but asks him not to reveal the truth to Yashu, fearing she might be disheartened to know that Raj, who she dotes on so much, is not her real child.

name: Extraction 2
synopsis: Back from the brink of death, highly skilled commando Tyler Rake takes on another dangerous mission: saving the imprisoned family of a ruthless gangster.

name: Scream
synopsis: There's a new Ghostface in town terrorizing teens, 25 years after Woodsboro's first killing spree — and old friends must reunite to stop the slaughter.
spoilers:
Rating 3: Twenty-five years after Billy Loomis and Stu Macher's killing spree in Woodsboro, high school student Tara Carpenter is home alone when she is attacked by Ghostface and left hospitalized.
Rating 8: In Modesto, Tara's estranged older sister Sam Carpenter is informed by Wes Hicks, one of Tara's friends, about the attack.
Rating 10: Sam returns to Woodsboro with her boyfriend Richie Kirsch to visit Tara at the hospital, where Sam is reunited with Tara's friend group: Wes, Amber Freeman, twins Chad and Mindy Meeks-Martin, and Liv McKenzie.
Rating 10: That night, Liv's ex-boyfriend Vince Schneider, who is Stu's nephew, is killed by Ghostface.
Rating 8: After an encounter with Ghostface at the hospital, Sam tells Tara that she has been dealing with hallucinations of Billy, who Sam learned as a teenager was her biological father.
Rating 8: Sam's true parentage resulted in their parents' separation and this is why Sam became estranged from Tara.
Sam and Richie visit Dewey Riley, who is divorced from Gale Weathers.
Rating 3: They ask for his help in stopping the killer, and he contacts Gale and Sidney Prescott, warning them about the return of Ghostface.
Rating 10: Dewey joins them at Mindy and Chad's home and is reunited with the twins' mother Martha, Randy Meeks' sister.
Rating 6: With the three attacks being on people related in some capacity to the original killers, Mindy deduces that the killer is following the rules of a "requel" – a continuation of a narrative that derives heavily from the plot of the original, while using Tara and her friends as the new generation and using Sam's connection to Billy as a way to weave the legacy characters.
Rating 6: Ghostface then murders Wes and his mother, Sheriff Judy Hicks, at their home.
Rating 10: Dewey reunites with Gale, who has arrived in town to cover the story.
Rating 8: At the hospital, Tara and Richie are attacked by Ghostface, but are saved by an arriving Dewey and Sam.
Rating 10: Sam, Tara and Richie escape, but Dewey is killed when he attempts to finish off Ghostface.
Rating 10: Sidney arrives in town after learning of Dewey's death and meets both Gale and Sam at the hospital.
Rating 10: Sidney asks Sam to help stop the killer, but Sam declines, choosing to leave town with Richie and Tara.
Rating 3: Sidney and Gale follow the trio to Amber's, which is revealed to be Stu's former home where the original Woodsboro massacre took place.
Rating 10: While a party is in progress to honor Wes' memory, Chad and Mindy are both attacked by Ghostface.
Rating 6: As the friend group convenes, Amber pulls out Dewey's gun and shoots Liv in the head, revealing herself as the killer.
Rating 10: Sidney and Gale arrive, and Richie is revealed as Amber's accomplice.
Rating 3: He stabs Sam, and he and Amber take Sam, Sidney, and Gale into the kitchen where Sidney had first faced off against Billy and Stu.
Rating 8: Richie and Amber reveal they are fans of the Stab film series who met online.
Rating 10: Disappointed in the trajectory taken with the most-recent Stab 8, they decided to embark on a new killing spree to bring back the "original cast" and provide new-and-improved "source material" for a future Stab film, then frame Sam as the killer.
Rating 3: Sam attacks Richie and Tara attacks Amber but is incapacitated; Richie goes after Sam while Sidney and Gale fight Amber together, ending with Gale breaking free and shooting Amber, who lands on a turned-on stove and is set on fire.
Rating 8: Richie pursues Sam, who sees another hallucination of Billy, which brings her attention to Amber's abandoned knife.
Rating 3: Embracing her paternal heritage, she uses the knife to stab Richie repeatedly and slitting his throat, before shooting and killing him.
Rating 10: A horribly burnt Amber attempts to attack the group again but is shot to death by Tara.
Rating 10: Tara and the Meeks twins are loaded into ambulances to be taken to the hospital, and Sam thanks Sidney and Gale for their help.
Rating 8: Gale promises not to write a new book about the new murders and give the killers notoriety, opting to write a tribute to Dewey instead.

name: Sindhooram
synopsis: A headstrong young man joins the police to fight injustice, but when corrupt officials label him a terrorist he takes the law into his own hands.
spoilers:
Rating 3: A cadre of police constables is on their way home from election duty.

Rating 8: He becomes a symbol of law and order in the 30 surrounding villages and is seen as a form of alternate government.
Rating 8: Bulliraju's training officer is designated the task of wiping Naxalism from the area.

Rating 8: Eventually, the police catch up to them and most of them die with heavy casualties on both sides.
Rating 10: The overall message of the movie is that when people have nothing to lose, they will not shy away from taking the law into their own hands.
Rating 7: When the common man is denied justice from official channels, he will seek justice from whoever will give it to him.
Rating 10: Justice is as important to the sustenance of a society as food and water.
Rating 7: When justice becomes a luxury, society turns to chaos and death becomes a way of life.
Rating 10: When a government doesn't provide the kind of justice that society needs, society will try to snatch it as a drowning man will grasp for air.

name: Stuart Little 2
synopsis: Trouble's in the air for spirited city mouse Stuart and family cat Snowbell when a new canary friend flies into danger with a ruthless falcon.
spoilers:
Rating 10: Set three years after the events of the first film, Stuart Little has settled into family life with his parents, older brother George, and baby sister Martha, who has yet to say her first words.
Rating 10: Stuart is becoming tired of his adoptive mother Eleanor's overprotectiveness due to his small size, and is finding himself lonely when George would rather play with his own friend, Will.
Rating 10: When playing by himself, Stuart accidentally wrecks George's toy plane, prompting George to furiously throw it into a trash can.
Rating 8: Stuart's adoptive father Frederick tells him there is a 'silver lining' to every bad situation, and encourages him to find a new friend of his own.
Rating 7: When driving home from school in his roadster, Stuart meets Margalo, a canary who falls into his car.
Rating 3: Margalo states she has injured her wing being chased by a predatory Falcon, and Stuart takes her home to recover.
Rating 10: Unbeknownst to the Littles, Margalo is in fact physically healthy, and is working with Falcon to steal precious items from households.
Rating 5: However, she soon bonds with the Littles, and feels immense guilt over what she is planning to do; Falcon warns her that if she does not complete their plan, he will kill Stuart.
Rating 10: Margalo steals Eleanor's ring, prompting Stuart to venture down the Littles' kitchen drain in an unfruitful attempt to find it again.
Rating 3: He soon finds himself in trouble, but Margalo rescues him; realizing the danger she is putting him in, she leaves the next morning.
Rating 8: Stuart becomes convinced Falcon has kidnapped her, and sets off to find her with the family cat Snowbell, convincing George to conduct a series of elaborate  lies to Eleanor in order to cover for him.
Rating 7: Stuart and Snowbell seek out street-cat Monty, who tells them that Falcon lives at the top of the Pishkin Building, and warns that he is an extremely dangerous foe.
Rating 3: Stuart uses a balloon to fly to the summit of the Pishkin Building, but is taken aback when Margalo reveals her alliance with Falcon.
Rating 10: Falcon traps Margalo in a paint can, and attempts to kill Stuart by dropping him from the sky; Stuart instead lands in a garbage truck and is taken to a garbage barge out at sea.
Rating 8: Initially devastated at the series of events, Stuart soon finds his silver lining by rediscovering and subsequently repairing George's broken toy plane, which he uses to fly back to land.
Rating 8: Meanwhile, George, after being reprimanded by his parents for lying and interrogated on Stuart's whereabouts, confesses where Stuart is to them, prompting them to head out and look for him.
Rating 8: In the meantime, Snowbell has also ventured up the Pishkin Building, and frees Margalo from the paint can, only to become trapped in it himself.
Rating 10: Margalo breaks free from Falcon's control, and flies away with Eleanor's ring, prompting Falcon to give chase.
Rating 10: Stuart arrives in his toy plane, and a furious chase occurs through New York, with the Littles following from behind.
Rating 5: Stuart ultimately wins the battle by using the ring to blind Falcon's vision, before jumping from the plane and allowing it to crash into Falcon as he falls into a trash can and is most likely eaten by Monty.
Rating 10: The day saved, Frederick and Eleanor forgive Stuart for running away and George for lying to them, and tell them they are extremely proud of them for their bravery.
Rating 10: Later, Margalo fulfills her dream of flying south for the winter, planning on returning to the Little household in the spring.
Rating 7: Martha stuns everyone by using her first words to say goodbye to Margalo.

name: Clifford the Big Red Dog
synopsis: After their tiny red puppy grows into a 25-foot giant, a young girl and her uncle must protect their lovable new pet from an evil genetics company.
spoilers:
Rating 8: In New York City, Emily Elizabeth Howard, a 12-year-old middle school student who lives with her English mother, Maggie, is regularly bullied by a popular girl at school named Florence, but finds comfort in her only new friend Owen Yu.
Rating 8: Maggie leaves her in the care of her van-dwelling and irresponsible uncle Casey before going to Chicago for a business trip.

Rating 10: He tells her that the puppy will grow based on how much love he receives.
Rating 10: Casey rejects the adoption due to dogs not being allowed in the apartment building.
Rating 3: When Emily gets home from school, she finds the puppy in her backpack and names him Clifford.
Rating 8: Casey allows her to keep Clifford only for one night.
Rating 10: The next morning, Clifford has grown to giant proportions.
Rating 10: Emily and Casey attempt to hide him from the building's superintendent, Mr. Packard.
Rating 7: They try taking Clifford to a veterinarian, but he chases and plays with a man in an inflatable bubble.
Rating 3: Word of his existence quickly spreads online.
Rating 3: After learning from the vet's secretary of Bridwell's past miracles with animals and their owners, the Howards plan to get information on his whereabouts.
Rating 10: As Emily is getting Clifford lunch from the cafeteria, Clifford escapes from Casey's truck and humiliates Florence, giving Emily the friends she always wanted.
Rating 3: Zac Tieran, the owner of biotechnology company Lyfegro, discovers Clifford on social media.
Rating 8: He lies to the police that Clifford is his dog and has them search for him.

Rating 10: If he cannot help, Clifford must be sent to China, where Owen's father has a sanctuary.
Rating 10: They race to the hospital, only to find Bridwell's empty bed and a patient who tells them Bridwell has died.

Rating 6: The next day, Clifford is captured on the ship by Lyfegro personnel and sent to Lyfegro.
Rating 5: Emily soon learns Bridwell did not die, so she and Casey try to save Clifford from being operated on at Lyfegro, aided by friends from their neighborhood.

name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
synopsis: The eccentric Willy Wonka opens the doors of his candy factory to five lucky kids who learn the secrets behind his amazing confections.
spoilers:
Rating 10: Charlie Bucket is a kind and loving boy who lives in poverty with his family near the Wonka Factory.
Rating 10: The company's owner, Willy Wonka, has long closed his factory to the public due to problems concerning industrial espionage, which also caused all his employees, including Charlie's Grandpa Joe, to lose their jobs.
Rating 10: Charlie's father, meanwhile, has more recently been laid off from his own job at a toothpaste factory, although he does not admit this to Charlie.
Rating 8: One day, Wonka announces a contest in which Golden Tickets have been placed in five random Wonka Bars worldwide, and the winners will receive a full tour of the factory as well as a lifetime supply of chocolate, while one will receive an additional prize at the end of the tour.
Rating 8: Wonka's sales subsequently skyrocket, and the first four tickets are found by the gluttonous Augustus Gloop, the spoiled Veruca Salt, the arrogant Violet Beauregarde, and the ill-tempered Mike Teavee.
Rating 10: Charlie tries twice to find a ticket, but both bars come up empty.
Rating 8: After overhearing that the final ticket was found in Russia, Charlie finds a banknote and purchases a third Wonka Bar.
Rating 8: The Russian ticket is revealed to be a forgery just as Charlie discovers the real ticket inside the wrapper.
Rating 3: He receives monetary offers for the ticket, but the cashier warns him not to trade it regardless, and Charlie runs back home.
Rating 9: At home, Charlie initially wants to trade the ticket for money for his family's betterment, but after a pep talk from Grandpa George, he decides to keep it and brings Grandpa Joe to accompany him on the tour.
Rating 10: Charlie and the other ticket holders are greeted outside the factory by Wonka, who then leads them into the facility.
Rating 10: Individual character flaws cause the other four children to give in to temptation, resulting in their elimination from the tour while Wonka's new employees, the Oompa-Loompas, sing a song of morality after each.
Rating 8: Meanwhile, Wonka reminisces on his troubled past and how his dentist father, Wilbur, strictly forbade him from consuming any candy.
Rating 3: After sneaking a piece of candy, Wonka instantly became hooked and ran away from home to follow his dreams.
Rating 10: When he returned, however, both his father and their house were gone.
Rating 7: After the tour, the four eliminated children leave the factory with an exaggerated characteristic or deformity related to their elimination while Charlie learns that Wonka, now approaching retirement, intended to find a worthy heir.
Rating 8: Since Charlie was the least ill-behaved of the five, Wonka invites Charlie to come live and work in the factory with him, provided that he leave his family behind.
Rating 10: Charlie declines, as his family is the most important thing in his life.
Rating 10: As Charlie and his family's life improve, Wonka becomes despondent, causing his company and sales to decline.
Rating 10: He eventually turns to Charlie for advice, and he decides to help Wonka reconcile with his estranged father, Wilbur.
Rating 10: During the reunion, Charlie notices newspaper clippings of Wonka's success which Wilbur collected, while Wonka realizes the value of family as he and Wilbur finally reconcile.
Rating 10: Afterwards, Wonka allows Charlie and his family to move into the factory together.
